ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got an in-depth course that guided me through thinking critically about my own values, aspirations, and to question and strengthen them. I realized it was less about what I do, but more about why I do it and who I do it with.
I learned about different religious and philosophical traditions and what they find as their life worth living. I was also able to develop my own vision of a life worth living.

I learned about how different cultures, philosophies, and traditions around the world view the meaning of a life worth living. I also had a very open cohort who was willing to engage with each others' visions under the guidance of our instructor.
Taught me to think very highly about life and how humans occupy space and history.
Learned all about different religions and philosophies for how one should live their life.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strength of the class really comes out when your class is able to bond on a more personal level.

Strengths: Matt and Estrella were a great teaching team. They really care about the students and want to get to know them beyond the classroom, which was nice. They did a good job facilitating discussions. Workload was manageable too. The retreat was a fun and meaningful, and I think the class grew close as a result. I liked the final paper and being able to read everyone else's final papers about our own visions of a life worth living. Weaknesses: I didn't always feel like we got to the crux of what different traditions identify as core tenets in their good life, and as a result it felt like a religious studies class at times. Grading was unnecessarily harsh. It was hard to stay engaged because the readings weren't the most captivating. Plenary was not super interesting or necessary either.

I think it is in general a good class if you are in the right mindset to take it. As a graduating senior, being preoccupied with day-to-day struggles like looking for a job made it harder to engage with the higher-level takeaways from the course. The readings strike a good balance of being accessible while also giving the topics at hand proper coverage and discussion. I really, really enjoyed the opportunity to peer-review the final papers - part of me wishes that all of the papers followed the same peer review structure. I don't know if I got as much out of the plenary speakers - sometimes they felt somewhat disorganized and disconnected from the topics we covered during class.
Literature was very interesting, but also very dense. I felt the amount of reading we were assigned did not match the depth of analysis in class.
Amazing course! Nearly a must take at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Hands down the best class I've had at Yale! I've been recommending this class to all of my friends.

I'd recommend this course with some reservations. I would recommend the section with Matt and Estrella because they are great. Matt is also the course director so he knows what he's doing. This was one of the few classes where I felt close with the other students --- starting with sharing our experiences on retreat, people were really invested in the course and that made my experience a lot better. With regards to the curriculum, some units felt disjointed and like they did not relate to a life worth living. The grading was super tough for no apparent reason, too. I liked the three paper topics, but I felt that, since the grading was so harsh, I was writing the papers not as I would actually write them, but how Matt and Estrella would want them. Nonetheless, I enjoyed the semester.

If you're pretty satisfied with your life as is and are looking to engage more - then yes! If that's not the case, and you think you'll be distracted by the things that are going on in your life right now, then probably not.
One of the best courses Ive taken at Yale! In a perfect world, everyone at Yale should take this course. This course changed my life and solidified my understanding of the world.
Yes, I think this is a very unique course, and I appreciate how much the professors are willing to engage with students.
Yes! Gives you interesting new perspectives on every day life.
